verses.text: After the death of Saul, when David had returned from defeating the Amalekites, he stayed in Ziklag for two days.
verses.comment: This transition marks the beginning of David's kingship following Saul's death. It recalls 1 Samuel 31 for context.

verses.text: On the third day, a man arrived from Saul’s camp with his clothes torn and dirt on his head. When he reached David, he fell to the ground and bowed down.
verses.comment: The torn clothes and dust signify mourning and distress, common symbols of grief in ancient Israel.

verses.text: David asked him, 'Where do you come from?' He replied, 'I have escaped from the camp of Israel.'
verses.comment: The survivor brings news to David about the disastrous defeat of Israel's army.

verses.text: David said, 'How did it go? Tell me.' He answered, 'The people fled from battle. Many fell and died. Saul and his son Jonathan are dead.'
verses.comment: The news of both Saul and Jonathan's deaths brings gravity and sets up David's lament.

verses.text: David asked the young man who brought him the report, 'How do you know Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?'
verses.comment: David seeks confirmation, underscoring the importance and seriousness of this news.

verses.text: The young man answered, 'I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and saw Saul leaning on his spear, with chariots and horsemen closing in on him.'
verses.comment: The account builds on Saul's tragic end at Mount Gilboa, emphasizing the desperate situation.

verses.text: 'When Saul turned and saw me, he called out to me. I answered, “Here I am.”'
verses.comment: The report here differs from 1 Samuel 31, showing another perspective on Saul's death.

verses.text: 'He asked me, “Who are you?” I answered, “I am an Amalekite.”'
verses.comment: Saul’s encounter with an Amalekite is ironic, considering Israel’s history with them (cf. 1 Sam. 15).

verses.text: 'Then he said to me, “Stand over me and kill me! I am in agony but still alive.”'
verses.comment: The Amalekite claims to have played a direct role in Saul's death, differing slightly from the earlier account.

verses.text: 'So I stood over him and killed him, because I knew he would not survive after falling. Then I took the crown from his head and the bracelet from his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.'
verses.comment: The Amalekite's story is likely self-serving. The crown and bracelet symbolize Saul's lost kingship. The differences with 1 Sam. 31 suggest possible embellishment.

verses.text: Then David took hold of his clothes and tore them, and so did all the men who were with him.
verses.comment: Tearing clothes is a sign of grief and mourning, echoing Israelite traditions of lament.

verses.text: They mourned, wept, and fasted until evening, for Saul and for his son Jonathan, and for the people of the LORD, and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
verses.comment: David's mourning is communal, inclusive, and devout. The act of fasting for the deceased highlights a pattern of prayerful intercession, seen in spiritual traditions of remembrance.

verses.text: David said to the young man who brought the report, 'Where are you from?' He replied, 'I am the son of an outsider, an Amalekite.'
verses.comment: Again, the Amalekite's outsider status is highlighted, tying back to Israel's enemies and reinforcing the severity of the moment.

verses.text: David said to him, 'How is it you were not afraid to stretch out your hand to destroy the LORD's anointed?'
verses.comment: David upholds the sanctity of God's anointed, reflecting a deep reverence for the divine office. This respect for spiritual authority lays the foundation for understanding rightful leadership.

verses.text: So David called one of the young men and said, 'Go, strike him down!' And he struck him and he died.
verses.comment: David ensures justice is served. The consequences for killing God's anointed highlights the seriousness of spiritual judgment against usurping God’s chosen leaders.

verses.text: David said to him, 'Your blood is on your own head, for your own mouth has testified against you, saying, “I killed the LORD's anointed.”'
verses.comment: Self-incrimination leads to judgment. This underscores the peril of rejecting divinely-instituted authority.

verses.text: Then David chanted a lament for Saul and for his son Jonathan.
verses.comment: Lamentation prayers for the dead are part of Israel’s spiritual heritage, demonstrating respect and invoking remembrance.

verses.text: He commanded that the song be taught to the people of Judah. It is called the Song of the Bow, and it is written in the Book of Jashar:
verses.comment: Reference to the Book of Jashar connects to Israel’s ancient literary traditions; the “Song of the Bow” underscores commemoration of heroism and remembrance.

verses.text: 'Your glory, O Israel, lies slain on your high places! How the mighty have fallen!'
verses.comment: David’s lament sets the tone for sacred remembrance over the loss of God’s chosen leaders.

verses.text: 'Do not tell it in Gath, do not proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.'
verses.comment: Israel’s humiliation at the hands of her enemies is lamented; secrecy protects Israel’s honor.

verses.text: 'Mountains of Gilboa, may no dew or rain fall on you, nor fields of offerings! For there the shield of the mighty was defiled, the shield of Saul—no longer anointed with oil.'
verses.comment: A curse upon the place of defeat. The ‘anointed’ recalls the sacred office and anointing with oil—a sign of election, later fulfilled in Christ (cf. Luke 4:18).

verses.text: 'From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan did not turn back, the sword of Saul did not return empty.'
verses.comment: Jonathan’s skill and Saul’s might are praised, highlighting valor and the realities of warfare.

verses.text: 'Saul and Jonathan, loved and adored in life, and not separated in death; they were swifter than eagles, stronger than lions.'
verses.comment: A poetic eulogy for their unity and strength. Foreshadows Christ's death uniting people, transforming defeat to victory spiritually.

verses.text: 'Daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet and finery, who adorned your garments with gold.'
verses.comment: David reminds Israel of Saul’s benefits, invoking national mourning and communal memory—similar to later traditions remembering departed faithful.

verses.text: 'How the mighty have fallen in the midst of battle! Jonathan lies slain on your high places.'
verses.comment: Repetition in lament intensifies emotional expression, suitable for use in prayerful reflection.

verses.text: 'I grieve for you, Jonathan my brother; you were exceptionally dear to me. Your love to me was extraordinary, greater than the love of women.'
verses.comment: Jonathan and David's deep friendship points to bonds that transcend mere family—spiritual fellowship prefigures the unity of God’s chosen people (cf. John 17:21).

verses.text: 'How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war are destroyed!'
verses.comment: The closing of the lament emphasizes the end of an era. It invites prayer for fallen leaders and remembrance, a motif that enriches both the literal and spiritual unity of God’s people.
